text: Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
